item.title: The Math Teaching Atlas: Trails, Anchors, and Compass in Action
item.description: arXiv:2504.04313v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper advocates a shift grounded in mathematical reasoning: teach through explicit routeways rather than narratives, anchor new ideas to familiar concepts on a roadmap, and use motivation and concrete examples as a compass and simulation for discovery.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Z. Feng

item.title: Mathematical theory of deep learning
item.description: arXiv:2407.18384v3 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: This book provides an introduction to the mathematical analysis of deep learning. It covers fundamental results in approximation theory, optimization theory, and statistical learning theory, which are the three main pillars of deep neural network theory. Serving as a guide for students and researchers in mathematics and related fields, the book aims to equip readers with foundational knowledge on the topic. It prioritizes simplicity over generality, and presents rigorous yet accessible results to help build an understanding of the essential mathematical concepts underpinning deep learning.
item.dc:creator: Philipp Petersen, Jakob Zech

item.title: Sophomore's dream function: asymptotics, complex plane behavior and relation to the error function
item.description: arXiv:2501.10936v4 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Sophomore's dream sum $S=\sum_{n=1}^\infty n^{-n}$ is extended to the function $f(t,a)=t\int_{0}^{1}(ax)^{-tx}dx$ with $f(1,1)=S$. Asymptotic behavior for a large $|t|$ is obtained, which is exponential for $t>0$ and $t<0,a>1$, and inverse-logarithmic for $t<0,a<1$. An advanced approximation includes a half-derivative of the exponent and is expressed in terms of the error function. This approach provides excellent interpolation description in the complex plane. The function $f(t,a)$ demonstrates for $a>1$ oscillating behavior along the imaginary axis with slowly increasing amplitude and the period of $2\pi iea$, modulation by high-frequency oscillations being present. Also, $f(t,a)$ has non-trivial zeros in the left complex half-plane with Im$t_n \simeq 2(n-1/8)\pi e/a$ for $a>1$. The results obtained describe analytical integration of the function $x^{tx}$.
item.dc:creator: V. Yu. Irkhin
